title: Russian Energy & Gas Policy as Political Weapon
summary: Russia uses its energy exports (natural gas, oil) as geopolitical leverage, particularly over Europe. Gazprom (state-controlled) can cut supplies to pressure countries politically. This leverage diminished after 2022 invasion as Europe diversified energy sources.

russian_perspective.official_narrative: Russia is a reliable energy supplier fulfilling contractual obligations. Any supply disruptions are due to technical issues, Western sanctions interfering with maintenance, or buyers refusing to pay in rubles. Europe's energy crisis is self-inflicted due to anti-Russian sanctions.

core_claims: Russia has been reliable energy partner for decades
Europe depends on Russian gas by choice (market economics)
Supply cuts are technical, not political
Western sanctions prevent turbine maintenance (Nord Stream excuse)
Europe's energy crisis caused by their own policies
Alternative suppliers (US LNG) more expensive and unreliable

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: We are fulfilling all our contractual obligations. We have never refused, no matter what anyone says, we have not refused to supply the necessary energy resources to the European market.

key_quotes.speaker: Gazprom
key_quotes.quote: Nord Stream gas pipeline will be fully stopped until the causes of the oil leak are eliminated.

western_perspective.official_narrative: Russia has repeatedly weaponized energy supplies to coerce and punish European countries. Pattern of cutting supplies during winter, political disputes, or negotiations. Ukraine has faced cuts multiple times. After 2022 invasion, Russia deliberately reduced EU gas to pressure sanctions removal.
evidence_cited: 2006 & 2009 gas cutoffs to Ukraine (January, coldest month)
Reduction of Nord Stream flows in 2022 (before any technical issues)
Gazprom's state ownership gives Kremlin direct control
Correlation between gas cuts and political disputes

verified_claims: Russia supplied ~40% of EU gas imports before 2022 invasion
Germany was most dependent (~55% of gas from Russia)
Russia cut gas to Ukraine in 2006 and 2009 (January)
Nord Stream 1 flows reduced to 20% capacity in July 2022
Nord Stream 1 shut down completely August 31, 2022
Nord Stream pipelines sabotaged September 26, 2022 (perpetrator disputed)
EU reduced Russian gas imports by 75% by late 2023
Europe found alternative suppliers (Norway, LNG from US/Qatar)
disputed_claims: Whether cuts were technical or political (pattern suggests political)
Who sabotaged Nord Stream pipelines (theories: Russia, US, Ukraine)
Whether sanctions prevented turbine maintenance (dubious - sanctions had exemptions)

propaganda_techniques_observed: Denial (energy cuts are technical, not political)
Blame shifting (Europe's crisis is their own fault)
False victimhood (sanctions prevent Russia from helping)
Economic coercion disguised as market forces
Selective evidence (citing contracts while violating spirit)

sources.description: IEA: Russia's Gas Cuts to Europe
